Problem:
The behavior of a complex function \\( z(t) = x(t) + iy(t) \\) is studied, where \\( i \\) is the imaginary unit and \\( x(t) \\) and \\( y(t) \\) are real functions of time governed by the coupled differential equations \\( \\dot{x} = ax - by \\) and \\( \\dot{y} = bx + ay \\), where a and b are constants. The impact of a transformation defined by \\( h(z) = e^{ct}z \\), where c is a real constant, is examined over time t.

Can the original complex number \\( z_0 \\) at t = 0 be precisely recovered after observing \\( z(t) \\) at t = T without knowing whether \\( h(z) \\) was applied?
Explanation: If the transformation has been applied, then the observed \\( z(t) \\) at t = T comes from a scaled version of the initial condition, and without knowledge of the application of \\( h(z) \\), it is impossible to uniquely recover \\( z_0 \\) since multiple initial conditions (scaled versions) can lead to similar trajectories under the differential equations.
